Legal_Issue: Whether Ms. Chan meets the residency requirement under s. 5(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Chan was physically present in Canada for only 162 days during the required four-year period
She pursued education abroad without attempting to return or enroll in Canadian programs
Her integration into Canadian society occurred after the application deadline
Court_Ruling: Application premature due to failure to meet residency requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absence from Canada (933 days) during the required period
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged compliance with residency through ties to Canada despite physical absence
Legal_Standard: Residency determined by physical presence and attachment to Canada
Assessment_Factor: Efforts to integrate into Canadian society
Procedural_Issue: Review of residency compliance by the court
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation of s. 5(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Timing of integration efforts in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicant must reside in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years before application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing temporary nature of absences
No attempt to maintain ties through enrollment or return
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; reapplication permitted upon fulfillment of residency requirement
Cause_Description: Ms. Chan applied for citizenship despite being absent from Canada for 933 days during the required period
Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed presence, family ties, and integration efforts
Evidence_Issues: Post-deadline integration not admissible for residency assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Absences not considered temporary; minimal physical presence
Decision_Rationale: Residency requires physical presence and genuine attachment during the qualifying period; Ms. Chan did not meet this standard
Evidentiary_Issues: Timing of integration efforts undermines claim of continuous residency intent
